I was looking for some enclosure ideas for my Replicator 2 and It dawned on me that if you coated one side of a 'wall' with mylar you could use just about anything to create the enclosure walls.

You'll need a sheet of mylar.    Mylar is very cheap. I found a 5ft by 6ft sheet of it for $2.99(USD) at Target  packaged as an emergency blanket in the camping section.  You should be able to find a similar product in a camping or military surplus store. Or you can just find out where the weather balloon people get theirs. I think you can flip around a helium party balloon also.  
You'll also want to make them removable. I chose to use black velcro tape from a craft store for $5.99 USD.  
Now find any sturdy material that you can cut into the proper shape to fit over the side holes. I used sheet of very stiff cardboard with a black side that shows through the hole. Like the box the Makerbot came in.  The end result is surprisingly stock looking and I'm willing to bet the mylar makes for a better heat box than acrylic but I have not yet had a chance to prove it.   
Now wrap the mylar around one side of your wall using the velcro tape to secure it.  Put the other side of the velcro tape on the wall of the Makerbot around the side port holes and you have partial enclosure for less than 10 dollars US.

description.text:
This is a skull mold for candy.  It was made from the original source model.
The mold was printed at 125% on an Ultimaker 2. Marshmallow fondant was molded to make skulls  for Day of the Dead. The students decorated the skulls with candy and icing (life savers for eyes, etc).
NGSS

This is a skull mold for candy.  It was made from the original source model.
The mold was printed at 125% on an Ultimaker 2. Marshmallow fondant was molded to make skulls  for Day of the Dead. The students decorated the skulls with candy and icing (life savers for eyes, etc).

• Mold the marshmallow fondant in the mold, a vegetable oil spray if it sticks to the mold
  • Decorate the marshmallow skull
  • Enjoy

• Print the Candy Mold, make several copies if you want the kids to mold their own instead of making them ahead of time.
  • Make the marshmallow fondant. There are many recipes online you can use.
  • Collect candy decorations - life savers, sprinkles, thin licorice, candy corn, mini chocolate chips, etc.

Objective Decorate a skull for the Mexican Day of the Dead Audience This was a 3rd grade project. It was a collaboration between the art teacher and the Spanish teacher. Preparation
  • Print the Candy Mold, make several copies if you want the kids to mold their own instead of making them ahead of time.
  • Make the marshmallow fondant. There are many recipes online you can use.
  • Collect candy decorations - life savers, sprinkles, thin licorice, candy corn, mini chocolate chips, etc.
    • Steps
  • Mold the marshmallow fondant in the mold, a vegetable oil spray if it sticks to the mold
  • Decorate the marshmallow skull
  • Enjoy
    • Results This project turned out very well. The art teacher reports that the 3D printed candy mold worked much better than forming the skulls by hand.

comments.text: Any pictures of the decorated skulls yet?

comments.text: No. The art teacher is doing the molding and decorating and has promised me pictures. She did show me a marshmallow fondant molded skull that wasn't decorated, to test the mold. It looked good.

This is a 12 tooth T5 pulley. The pulley has also been made to use two M3 nuts and two set screws. Note: if you are switching from the standard 8 toothed Prusa Mendel pulley you will need to reset your X and Y axes steps/unit in your firmware. You can use the handy dandy RepRapCalculator by Prusajr to find your steps/unit: https://github.com/prusajr/RepRapCalculator Update: The stl file has been updated with smaller nut traps. We've added the native Solidworks file and a STEP file for those who want to import it into another CAD software. Licensing

title: Girl Scout Trefoil Emblem Cookie Cutter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Cutter and Stamp with handle using the design of the Girl Scouts emblem.
This was done with a new and much simpler technique.

SVG to SCAD Using the Inkscape SVG to SCAD export plugin, I generated an SVG of the Girl Scouts emblem. Additionally I used a series of transpositions and fills to produce a version with just the background field. This I exported also. Assembly in OpenSCAD I used the generated SCAD files as the starting point for my emblem. I wanted the inverse of the generated model so I differenced the emblem from the field. I created the edge of the stamp by offsetting the base by 1mm and differencing the original from it. The same technique was used for both the cutter and its handgrip. Finally the handle came from a personal library of OpenSCAD function.

This is the first upload of this robot giving it its basic functions. More uploads will be coming shortly with a variety of heads to attach to the effector so watch this space! Currently thinking of grippers, camera, torch, magnet...any suggestions would be appreciated! The robot is controlled using a program I have written in processing, I am currently writing a tutorial on Instructables for the assembly of the robot and the control. For this project you must print 3 DeltaRobotArm.stl's, 1 DeltaRobotEffector.stl, and 24 DeltaRobotSpacer.stl's. You will also need:
  • 6 Aluminium Rods
  • 12 Rose Joints to go on the Rods
  • 6 Steel Threaded Rods
  • Nuts
  • 3 HS805BB Servos
  • Arduino
  • Some Stand to put it on

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20

Notes: Printed on my Prusa i3. Adjust the infill especially of the arms to increase strength of the print, however with a large infill the print takes a long time!! I printed with ABS at 235 with the heated bed at 100 using Kapton Tape with Acetone ABS Glue to stop warping. As the arms are quite long and narrow warping can occur so try to either add a brim or keep print warm in an enclosure.

Finishing your print After using Acetone ABS Glue you may find your print is stuck to the bed like a determined limpet. This is both a blessing and a curse as you have had no warping hopefully but its stuck there! Try going round the edges with a knife or use a filler chisel/wallpaper stripper to get underneath your print. Good luck! Once your print is off the bed, you can remove and brim with a knife if you printed with brims. Then sand the print using gradually finer paper to get a good finish. Drill out the holes in the prints to accommodate the size of rods and bolts you used. I used 3mm bolts to attach the servo arm to the delta robot arm. I also used 6mm Steel threaded rod.

This is a Fifth Element themed Iphone 6 phone case. I took an existing basic case and added the Multi Pass elements to create a Multi Pass phone case. I also created a label file which is included as a PDF. Replace the photos and address with your own so if you lose your phone they know where to return it! 
I've had the best luck printing it out in 2 parts, gluing them together with CA glue and post finishing with XTC-3D with Aluminum Powder from Smooth-On. www.smooth-on.com.
Enjoy printing and have fun with this.

Thingiverse is full of ATX-to-general-PSU conversions. Why I created another one? Because I did not want the outputs directly on the ATX PSU. I want them on separate box connected to PSU by cable.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Mechanical setup The box is held together with four M4x40 screws with socket heads. Electrical setup There is lot of instructions how to convert ATX PSU to general purpose one. For example this on WikiHow. So, I provide just a quick cheat sheet on wire colors:
  • Black = ground
  • Yellow = +12 V
  • Red = +5 V
  • Orange = + 3.3 V
  • White = -5 V
  • Blue = -12 V
  • Gray or Brown = "power good" signal +5 V; connect to LED trough 330 ohm resistor and to the ground
  • Green = on/off; connect to ground trough power switch.

I created a 3D text of the MakerBot name/logo that you can print out to add bling to your printer or maybe blend into other objects like key chains or what have you.  I created this in Solidworks (because that is what I know) so I attached the native part file in addition to the STL file.
My daughter and I finished building our Makerbot Thing-O-Matic last week and we decided to paint it red on the outside and white on the inside.  This obliterated the nice logo's that Makerbot prints on the wood, so that is what we decided to create this 3D printed logo to attach onto the front of the bot.

Scale it if you like and print it out.  It is a quick print since it is small.  I decided to paint it white then touch up the faces with red to match my painted bot.  You could do a multi-color print too if you liked, but I only have the 1 pound natural ABS roll that came with my bot....I have lots more on order.  Use double stick tape to attach to your machine.

This is an H-type Quadcopter for 8.5 mm motors. Motor holes are made to be 8.25 mm for quadcopter_bottom/quadcopter_bottom_2 and 8.5 mm for quadcopter_bottom_3 (for bad quality 3D printers)
  • I Still haven't tried printing the design myself, so you can either wait for a week or two or print it now and tell me how did it go.
  • I plan to use http://micro-motor-warehouse.com/products/cl-0820-15-11t high speed motors, but you can also use Hubsan X4 (107C or 107D) motors for this frame.
  • I put some more branches in the body as I plan to use this frame for making an arduino quadcopter.
  • Quadcopter_bottom_2 has additional small rings, which I will use for testing purposes - will connect ropes to these places to hold the quadcopter in place. Later on I might use these places from propeller protectors that I might design later on...
  • (Recommended) Quadcopter_bottom_3 has a wider hole of 8.5 mm, which takes account of the expansion of the plastic, which happens often 3D printers using cheaper plastic. It was also redesigned to put the top part nicely, because I couldn't put in the screws after I printed them using cheaper plastic. In the picture this is the black bottom part.
  • (Recommended) Quadcopter_top_2 has additional places for camera/LEDs. Sizes of holes there are exactly 5 mm on the outside with internal bigger hole of 6 mm, which perfectly fits for 5 mm LEDs. I also fixed the letter "O" in this one as previously it didn't have the connection to body.
  • Quadcopter_screw_2 is a lied on the side an modified a bit version of previous Quadcopter_screw. This can now be uploaded directly to a 3D printer.
  • The design is dedicated for M.O.N.T.E. (Mobile Omnidirectional Neutralization and Termination Eradicator); for those who used to watch The Big Bang Theory.
  • I created this using TinkerCAD, thus you can always go there and edit things the way you want to https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7cnsWwxXek4

• Quadcopter_bottom_2 had some flaws. 1) I couldn't fit my 8.5 mm motors in. The fault is probably both mine and the printer as firstly, I designed the holes to be 8.25 mm, thinking that then motors could hold there strongly and secondly, the plastic expanded more than I predicted due to the fault in the printer, which later on was fixed, but I already had redesigned the bottom part and thus just tried printing it instead. 2) as I lifted some middle parts about a mm up, the printer couldn't handle this so the design looked not very pleasant after printing it. Both of these problems were addressed and fixed with an improved Quadcopter_bottom_3 design, which I tested to be working really well.
  • Quadcopter_screw could not fit in the holes of top and bottom parts. I addressed this problem by redesigning Quadcopter_bottom_3, which now has wider holes where you place the top part so it would not move after putting it on. Now you don't even need Quadcopter_screw anymore and can additionally bind these two parts using lets say plastic ties.

title: Print a Llama for your Mama

description.text:
Print a llama for your mama, or print yourself some llama parts and make a fun little buddy you can hang out with. This leaping llama can travel on your rear view mirror or chill on your wall. Add string to make him jump! And if you pull each string individually he can do any dance step you want. 
You will need to print 1 front, 1 back, 1 tail, 1 head, 1 pull, 2 supports, and 4 legs or 10 pieces in total.

Adding the String Legs Pulleys - It is best to thread the string through the holes before you snap the body pieces together. You can either use one piece of string for both of the front/back legs or one piece for each of the four individual legs. Thread these strings through the small holes in the legs, and then all of the ends should go down through the pull (grass shaped) and knotted. Hanger Piece - One piece of string should go through the back support, then up through the tail, then down through the head, and then through the front support. Knots should be tied under each support, or in the middle of the llama.

I designed this a couple of weeks ago. The pulleys look good when printed, but at least when using a standard .5mm nozzle, the teeth are not "sharp" enough and the timer belt slips too easy. When MakerGear published their z pulleys ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1081 ) I asked how they managed to avoid the slipping. Well, they use a .4mm nozzle... Since MakerGear asked for my design: Here it is. Again: These pulleys print nicely and also kind of work. The only thing is, that the timer belt doesn't get enough grip on its teeth at .5mm printing. The gcode file contains the object, processed for .5mm nozzles!

• Print the pulley (you might want to create your own .4 or .3mm gcode file :)
  • Insert a M3 nut and a M3 set screw

title: Adjustable z-limit for Rigidbot with Peter Stoneham linear bearing holders

description.text:
This mounts on top of Peter Stoneham's linear bearing mount on a Rigidbot. An M3 socket head cap screw threads through the part to make contact with the z limit switch allowing for easy micro-adjustment of the z limit. This was inspired by Pureluck's design ( http:www.thingiverse.com/thing:781168 ) for the original Rigidbot plastic linear bearing mount, but redesigned from scratch to fit Peter's stainless mount.
The mounting holes are slightly oversize for the 3 mm mounting bolts. The intent is to use washers under the nut or bolt head and compress the part to the frame. The adjustment bolt should thread nicely. Put a pair of nuts locked together on the end of that bolt to make clean contact with the limit switch.

remixed_from.title: Cut your own gears with profile shift - OpenSCAD library

description.text: Inspired by the_digital_dentist's SnakeBite extruder, I attempted to make a version that didn't require special parts or machining. The idea was to orient M3 bolts in such a way as to create a right-handed "thread" on one gear and left-handed on the other. That way the filament would be moved in the same direction by the gears rotating in opposite directions. It works but not well enough. Rotating the gear does move the filament along but also cuts out plastic debris. If the filament is held with enough force, it strips. I only experimented with using one gear and rotating it by hand but it's enough to let me know this particular setup isn't viable. In the process of making this I discovered Parkinbot's excellent gear generation script: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:636119 I've posted this failure so others could learn from it or maybe spark new ideas.

Cute little fox <3

One of the first things I designed and printed for my Thing-O-Matic was a cover for the Arduino/motherboard opening in the side of the bot.  The cover has holes in the right places for the USB cable, SD card and reset button.  the cover replaces two of the 3/4" spacers under the motherboard and that is how it is held in place.  
I think it cleans up the look of the printer and maybe protects the motherboard from being poked at by curious little fingers.

Print it out.  I oriented the part so it was face down on the build surface and printed raftless, so the show face is nice and smooth.
I printed out the label on a color printer using Avery label stock.  Then covered the label with clear packaging tape to protect it.  Roughly cutout the label and placed it on the printed part.  Then use a Xacto knife to carefully cut all the openings using the 3D part edges to guide the knife.  
Then install under the motherboard.

comments.text: I just made one of these.  This is a must print for anyone just starting out.  Not only is it very proffesional looking, but it is the perfect way to protect all electronics in the Thing-O-Matic.  After all it would really put a damper on your day if you accidentally discharged a static charge onto your Arduino.

title: two tone knob for cabinet doors

description.text:
I added a couple new cabinets to our kitchen, only to find out that Ikea is no longer selling the “Snodd” knob that we used on all the other cabinets.
I designed a two tone layout that replicates the look of the “Snodd” Knob. It houses an M4 Nut (ISO 4032) for screw in fixture and is compatible to the IKEA screws.
The inlay snaps right in with some pressure, you might need to clean up some leftovers from the support since it fits nice and tight. You should here two clicks once you push the inlay in then it its tight.
Prints come with a thin support disc that should peel of just fine. Make sure to cut /drill through the support material of the shell print… ;)
Printed on a Replicator 2 Sailfish with @100micron sliced with RepG (whpthomas profiles) at 30% infill with 4 Shells for solid colors…

title: Nautilus Gear - One Sided with Threads

description.text:
I loved playing with the one-sided version of the nautilus gears and wanted to make a few improvements. I replaced the caps with threads and nuts, and made a couple versions where the base is easier to hold. The nuts can be secured with glue, or by coupling them to prevent unscrewing.
Thanks to MishaT for the original gear model, alex80it for the one sided version, j1vvy for the idea to add threads, and mike_linus for the bolt library.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes: You'll need:
2x or 4x "Nautilus_Nut_Thin.stl" (you can lock together a pair of nuts on each post to prevent loosening)
2x "Nautilus_Gear.stl"
1x of either "Nautilus_ThreadedBase" (Thin will print faster, Fancy is easier to hold) Note that "Nautilus_ThreadedBase_Fancy.stl" has cylindrical voids to reduce material, which also provide another place to grip.

title: Multi-use Modular Tool Box and Screw Box

description.text:
This super handy container is simple and provides a variety of functions. It's primary function is as a single part. I use it to store all the screws and bolts when I'm working on DIY or Some Assembly Required projects. Instead of having screws lost throughout the workshop this little box keeps everything together. The slot in the front makes it easy to dump everything into a container (plastic bag / original box) when you are finished. 
The second function is as a storage container. If you've printed both the lid and the base then you have 2 screw catchers to use in your project. When you reach a stopping point just put the lid on the box and you have a robust container to make sure everything stays the way you left it. This would also be good for long term storage of smaller parts. The parts can be scaled to fit your storage needs. 
Finally, you can fill the base with parts that you need frequently and orient the 2 notches together. This creates a dispenser hole in the boxes so you can shake out a controllable quantity much like tick tacks.

Instructions We had a old HP Printer motor with a worm gear lying around, so here is how i adapted it to the design from onkel georg: -Lasercut the frame, inserted the bearings, fastened the bearings with self tapping screws so they dont fall out over the hours it is running (important!) -Using the rollers from the original design, but changed the gears: since this was a custom job i didnt include the gear design in the files, search for a gear customizer in thingiverse ;) -Its easier to laser the frame without mounting holes and adapt the motor once the basic structure is build by drilling the mounting holes (i used schelle.stl to fasten the motor)

  • https://youtu.be/hlATeBRlB9E
  • http://wp.me/p6xTQ3-ek

See in Sketchfab at https://skfb.ly/HYMW The base frame and phone shelf are easily adjustable to fit most common smartphone models. A sliding fixture holder allows for adjustment of the object-to-camera distance as well as the focus and framing of the image. A rubber-band-activated lever makes it easy to insert and remove the smartphone from the shelf and keeps it in place during photography.

The following fixtures are included in this kit:
  • Vertical fixture for eight positions at 45° intervals (for #3DBenchy)
  • Horizontal fixture for top-bottom positions at 45° intervals (for #3DBenchy)
  • Crank-actuated rotary platform for recording 360° videos (for #3DBenchy)
  • Crank-actuated rotary platform for recording 360° videos (blank)
  • Blank fixture insert with center-hole for generic objects
The frame components have holes through which the camera rig can be secured permanently on a flat surface.
A slot in the fixture holder can be used for mounting a sheet of paper which removes background clutter during photography.
A universal holder for flashlights can be used to add key lights and improve the clarity of the photos. The files for the holder can be downloaded from: http://thingiverse.com/thing:1017689
A separate holder for sheets of paper is included which can be used as additional light bouncers.

All files in this camera rig can be downloaded as individual STL files and also as pre-packed ready-to-print build plates. These are available for two commonly used square and rectangular build-volume sizes - 200 x 200 x 115 mm and 230 x 150 x 115 mm. If your 3D printer can make objects of this size or larger, then you can 3D-print a full plate in one go. Otherwise all individual parts can be 3D-printed within 150 x 150 x 114 mm.

Even though this rig is primarily designed to be used for photographing #3DBenchy specimens, it can nevertheless be used for taking photos of anything that fits in the camera's field of view. For this purpose the fixture insert is made available as a blank in both STEP and STL file formats. These can be easily adapted in your 3D/CAD software for holding items such as follows:
  • Stamps
  • Insects
  • Flowers
  • Leafs
  • Miniatures
  • Toy figurines
  • And anything else you can think of!
    • During the development and testing phase of this rig, it became obvious that it also works as a stand for mobile phones. Just make yourself comfortable, place the rig on your belly and effortlessly watch your favourite videos.

This 3D-printable camera rig is released as an open design and we encourage you to 3D-print it and make improvements to best fit your personal use. If you re-publish the new files please give this project attribution. :)
Please visit http://3DBenchy.com to learn more about 3D printing Concept and 3D model by http://Creative-Tools.com

comments.text:
The rig would have to work in a way that is opposite to this one. The camera would need to rotate around the object. I think of it like the solar system models you see. The Sun is stationary and the planets can rotate freely around it on their arms. The rig would work best if there was also an arm directly opposite the camera holder that can hold a piece of paper. The holder should bend the paper slightly concave so the background remains the same as the camera and it rotates around the center.
I have a clear picture of what I mean, unfortunately I don't have the CAD skills to draw it up.
comments.author: CreativeTools

comments.text: The issue with 123D is it uses the cameras accelerometer to get the angles. The camera needs to move around the print, not the other way around.
comments.author: CreativeTools

comments.text: Not sure if it uses the accelerometer, but an important factor is that the object is not allowed to move in relation to the environment. If the object moves, but the background doesn't, the software gets confused. The software uses visual cues in the background just as much as on the object itself to calculate the camera angles.

title: Double extruder mod Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
This is an experiment to mount two extruders as close as possible to each other on the Printrbot simple Metal with no modification of the printer itself. Print with as much infill as possible for rigidity. Not strong enough for real intensive or prolonged use, but perfect for proof of concept and experimenting. Bottom must be as flat and straight as possible. I recommend using a heated bed if possible, or if rafts are used, sand the bottom surface well since it will determine the parallelism of both extruders and their alignment with the Y axis. You might have to shorten the shaft of on of the two motors for them to fit.
The original Printrbot fan shroud, or any fan shroud made to fit standard extruders wont fit because of the hot ends being 5mm higher. Good luck :-)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
Both extruder installed face to face with a fan. First test of the dual extrusion mod after setting their position correctly.
